result.execSummary:
The defendant Reed O. Christopherson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess w/ Intent-Amphetamine(<=3g), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(e)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: 11:49  Defendant Reed O. Christopherson in court with attorney Julie A. Weber.  Defendant Reed O. Christopherson in custody.  Sean Edward Froelich appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Thorie addresses the report and gives recomendation.  Total  4-5 yr prison system  2 yrs conf  3 yrs es. 138 days credit.  Atty Weber requests 1 year in the County Jail with huber . records.addlTxt: 2:47 Defendant Reed O. Christopherson not in court.  William H. Thorie appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Atty THorie and Atty Caplan both have reviewed the PSI and neither have any changes to notes. Thorie: follow the recommendations in full by DOC. 3 years probation: incorporate all conditions from PSI. Asks for 6 months jail. Atty Caplan agrees with recommendation but with the least amount of jail time possible. Def addresses the jail. Court: S/W 3 years probation. Conditions: set forth on PSI.   No consumption of alcohol or illegal drugs allowed. May only have the prescribed amount of prescription drugs. no contact with any known drug user or dealer. DNA sample and court costs. No entry into any tavern. Comply with any programming. Supervision fees. 6 months jail stayed until December 30, 2016 at 7 pm,  huber allowed under the Sheriff's rules. Release day will be June 30, 2017.  Appeal rights are given to the defendant.
copy was faxed to Atty Thorie and Atty Caplan
Sentencing hearing on November 7, 2016 at 03:15 pm.

3:48 Defendant Reed O. Christopherson in court with attorney Allan Hart Caplan.  William H. Thorie appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Atty thorie parties have reached agreement & will enter plea agreement & states agreement.   Plea Questionnaire and Waiver of Rights form is filed with the court; court reviews with Def. Court Rights explained &  Exam'd re: understanding of law, penalty and rights. Defendant pleads to Count 1 in amended information  Possession with intent to deliver less that 3 grams. Class F felony.Rights explained. Exam re understanding of rights.    Facts are correct COURT ACCEPTS PLEA, FINDS DEF FREELY, INTELLIGENTLY, KNOWINGLY & UNDERSTANDINGLY MADE AND WAIVES CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHTS.  Amended information to be filed with the court. Count 2 is dismissed Court orders  PSI to be done &  Atty Thorie asks for continuance of bond and a condition to be added to the bond that the defendant cooperate with the completion of the PSI .        Signature bond to continue in current form. Sentencing to be scheduled in 60 days. 3:59.
Motion hearing on August 30, 2016 at 03:30 pm.
from Atty Caplan to appear via phone for PTC tomorrow. Atty Thorie has no objection.

Information Filed with the Court and a copy is given to the defendant.  Atty Caplan will have 10 days to filed any motions.   Defendant has a copy of the information  and waives reading of the information.   Defendant enters not guilty pleas to counts 1 and 2 of amended information at preliminary hearing.   Not guilty pleas received by the court.   The bond will continue as ordered and court reviews with the defendant.  Pretrial Conference to be set.

The court finds probable cause and binds defendant over for further proceedings.

3:41 Defendant Reed Otto Christopherson in court  VIA VIDEO CONFERENCING FROM PCJ, in custody.  William H. Thorie appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Atty Liesl Nelson appeared in court.   Defendant has copy of complaint.  Court reads charges and possible penalties.  Defendant waives reading of the complaint.  Constitutional rights explained to defendant.
